'''Neil McGill Gorsuch'''  ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɡ|ɔːr|s|ʌ|tʃ}} {{respell|GOR|sutch}};<ref name="pronounce">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2017/live-updates/trump-white-house/neil-gorsuch-confirmation-hearings-updates-and-analysis-on-the-supreme-court-nominee/how-to-pronounce-gorsuch/ |title=How to pronounce Gorsuch |date=March 22, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=April 3, 2017 |archive-date=April 4, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404043146/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2017/live-updates/trump-white-house/neil-gorsuch-confirmation-hearings-updates-and-analysis-on-the-supreme-court-nominee/how-to-pronounce-gorsuch/ |url-status=live}}</ref> born August 29, 1967) is an American lawyer and judge who serves as an [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States|associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/07/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court.html |title=Senate Confirms Gorsuch as Supreme Court Justice |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 7, 2017 |access-date=April 7, 2017 |archive-date=April 29, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190429054521/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/07/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court.html |url-status=live}}</ref> He was [[Neil Gorsuch Supreme Court nomination|nominated]] by President [[Donald Trump]] on January 31, 2017, and has served since April 10, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/news-wrap-alabama-governor-resigning-ethics-charges/ |title=News Wrap: Alabama governor resigning over ethics charges |work=PBS NewsHour |access-date=April 11, 2017 |language=en-US |archive-date=April 11, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170411072811/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/news-wrap-alabama-governor-resigning-ethics-charges/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Barnes">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-picks-colo-appeals-court-judge-neil-gorsuch-for-supreme-court/2017/01/31/2b08a226-e55e-11e6-a547-5fb9411d332c_story.html |title=Trump picks Colo. appeals court judge Neil Gorsuch for Supreme Court |last=Barnes |first=Robert |date=January 31, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=February 1, 2017 |archive-date=February 1, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201013448/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-picks-colo-appeals-court-judge-neil-gorsuch-for-supreme-court/2017/01/31/2b08a226-e55e-11e6-a547-5fb9411d332c_story.html |url-status=live}}</ref>

Gorsuch was born in and spent his early life in [[Denver, Colorado]], then lived in [[Bethesda, Maryland]], while attending [[Georgetown Preparatory School]]. He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Columbia College (New York)|Columbia University]], a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Harvard Law School|Harvard University]], and after practicing law for 15 years, received a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] degree in law from the [[University of Oxford]], which he attended as a [[Marshall Scholarship|Marshall Scholar]]. His doctoral thesis concerned the morality of [[assisted suicide]], under the supervision of the Catholic legal philosopher [[John Finnis]].<ref name="dphil"/><ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/judges/judge-neil-m-gorsuch |title=Judge Neil M. Gorsuch|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202050829/http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/judges/judge-neil-m-gorsuch|archive-date=February 2, 2017 |website=Administrative Office of the United States Courts |publisher=The United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>

From 1995 to 2005, Gorsuch was in private practice with the law firm of [[Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick]]. He was Principal Deputy Associate Attorney General at the [[United States Department of Justice]] from 2005 until his appointment to the Tenth Circuit. President [[George W. Bush]] nominated Gorsuch to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit]] on May 10, 2006, to replace Judge [[David M. Ebel]], who took [[senior status]] in 2006.

Gorsuch is a proponent of [[textualism]] in [[statutory interpretation]] and [[originalism]] in interpreting the [[United States Constitution]].<ref name=3judges/><ref name=contender/><ref name=scalia/> Along with Justice [[Clarence Thomas]], he is an advocate of [[Natural law|natural law jurisprudence]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/the-big-idea/2017/3/20/14976926/gorsuch-natural-law-supreme-court-hearings |title=Neil Gorsuch's "natural law" philosophy is a long way from Justice Scalia's originalism |last=Kelleher |first=J. Paul |date=March 20, 2017 |work=Vox |access-date=March 9, 2018 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231839/https://www.vox.com/the-big-idea/2017/3/20/14976926/gorsuch-natural-law-supreme-court-hearings |url-status=live}}</ref> Gorsuch clerked for Judge [[David B. Sentelle]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit]] from 1991 to 1992 and [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] justices [[Byron White]] and [[Anthony Kennedy]] from 1993 to 1994. He is the first Supreme Court justice to serve alongside a justice for whom he once clerked (Kennedy).<ref>{{cite news |last1=Livni |first1=Ephrat |title=Neil Gorsuch is the first US Supreme Court justice to sit on the bench with his high-court boss |url=https://qz.com/953345/neil-gorsuch-is-the-first-us-supreme-court-justice-to-sit-on-the-bench-with-his-high-court-boss/ |access-date=August 16, 2017 |work=Quartz |date=April 7, 2017}}</ref> During his tenure on the Supreme Court he has written notable opinions in landmark cases such as ''[[Bostock v. Clayton County]]'', ''[[McGirt v. Oklahoma]]'', and ''[[Kennedy v. Bremerton School District]]''.

== Early life and education ==
Gorsuch was born on August 29, 1967, in [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]], to [[Anne Gorsuch Burford]] (née McGill; 1942–2004) and David Ronald Gorsuch (1937–2001).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.biography.com/law-figure/neil-gorsuch|access-date=1 October 2021|title=Neil Gorsuch|archive-date=August 16, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210816160258/https://www.biography.com/law-figure/neil-gorsuch|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/David-Gorsuch/6000000053652938864 |title=David Ronald Gorsuch |publisher=geni.com |access-date=November 27, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231724/https://www.geni.com/people/David-Gorsuch/6000000053652938864 |url-status=live }}</ref> He was the eldest of three children,<ref name="NYT_Mother">{{cite web |last1=Liptak |first1=Adam |last2=Baker |first2=Peter |last3=Fandos |first3=Nicholas |last4=Turkewitz |first4=Julie |title=In Fall of Gorsuch's Mother, a Painful Lesson in Politicking |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/04/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court-nominee.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=17 May 2021 |date=4 February 2017 |archive-date=May 17, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210517222710/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/04/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court-nominee.html |url-status=live }}</ref> and is a fourth-generation Coloradan.<ref name="flyfish">{{cite news |title=Meet Neil Gorsuch: A fly-fishing Scalia fan |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/31/politics/neil-gorsuch-antonin-scalia/index.html |first=Ariane |last=de Vogue |work=CNN|date=February 1, 2017 |access-date=February 1, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231835/https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/31/politics/neil-gorsuch-antonin-scalia/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Both of Gorsuch's parents were lawyers, and his mother served in the [[Colorado House of Representatives]] from 1976 to 1980. In 1981, she was appointed by President [[Ronald Reagan]] to be the [[Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency|administrator]] of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]], becoming the first woman to hold that position.<ref name=fed>{{cite web |url=http://www.fed-soc.org/experts/detail/neil-gorsuch |title=Hon. Neil Gorsuch |publisher=The Federalist Society |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170125080902/http://www.fed-soc.org/experts/detail/neil-gorsuch |archive-date=January 25, 2017 }}</ref><ref name=emerges>{{cite news |title=Conservative Colorado judge emerges as a top contender to fill Scalia's Supreme Court seat |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-supreme-court-gorsuch-20170123-story.html |first=David G. |last=Savage |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=January 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name=WashPo19Feb>{{cite news |last1=Kindy |first1=Kimberly |last2=Horwitz |first2=Sari |last3=Wan |first3=William |title=Simply stated, Gorsuch is steadfast and surprising |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/simply-stated-gorsuch-is-steadfast-and-surprising/2017/02/18/4015bf18-f153-11e6-8d72-263470bf0401_story.html |access-date=February 20, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 19, 2017 |page=A1 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231852/https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/simply-stated-gorsuch-is-steadfast-and-surprising/2017/02/18/4015bf18-f153-11e6-8d72-263470bf0401_story.html |url-status=live }}</ref> At his mother's appointment, Gorsuch's family moved to [[Bethesda, Maryland]]. He attended [[Georgetown Preparatory School]], a prestigious [[Jesuit]] [[College-preparatory school|prep school]], where he was two years junior to [[Brett Kavanaugh]], alongside whom he later clerked at the Supreme Court and eventually served as a Supreme Court justice.<ref name="auto1">[http://www.denverpost.com/2017/02/10/neil-gorsuch-religion Neil Gorsuch - Religion], Denverpost.com, February 10, 2017; accessed February 25, 2017.</ref><ref name="auto2">{{cite web |url=https://www.gprep.org/about/alumni/notable-alumni |title=Notable Alumni |publisher=Georgetown Preparatory School |access-date=February 25, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231820/https://www.gprep.org/about/alumni/notable-alumni |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=family>{{cite news |title=10th Circuit judge's oath a family affair |url=http://www.denverpost.com/2006/11/20/10th-circuit-judges-oath-a-family-affair |first=Elizabeth |last=Aguilera |newspaper=[[The Denver Post]] |date=November 20, 2006}}</ref>  While attending Georgetown Prep, Gorsuch served as a [[Page of the United States Senate|United States Senate page]] in the early 1980s.<ref>{{Cite book |date=July 20, 2006 |title=Senator Mark Udall in support of Neil M. Gorsuch for Tenth Circuit Judge |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W6gziQydtBwC&q=%22Congressional+Record%22+Gorsuch&pg=PA291 |journal=[[Congressional Record|Congressional Record--Senate]] |via=[[Google Books]] |volume=152 |issue=11 |page=15384 |access-date=June 12, 2017 |isbn=978-0-16-086155-0 |last1=Congress |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231826/https://books.google.com/books?id=W6gziQydtBwC&q=%22Congressional+Record%22+Gorsuch&pg=PA291 |url-status=live }}</ref> He graduated from Georgetown Prep in 1985.

After high school, Gorsuch attended [[Columbia University]] and graduated ''[[Latin honors#North America|cum laude]]'' in 1988 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[political science]]. While at Columbia, Gorsuch was inducted into [[Phi Beta Kappa]].<ref name=fed/><ref name=record/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Clarke |first1=Sara |title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Neil Gorsuch |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-01-31/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-neil-gorsuch |access-date=February 2, 2017 |work=U.S. News & World Report |date=January 31, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231856/https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-01-31/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-neil-gorsuch |url-status=live }}</ref> He was also a member of [[Phi Gamma Delta]] fraternity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/columbia-classmates-recall-gorsuchs-time-new-york-scotus-trump |title=Columbia Classmates Recall Judge Neil Gorsuch's Time in New York |date=February 1, 2017 |website=[[WNYC]] |first=Annemarie |last=Fertoli |access-date=February 9, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231840/https://www.wnyc.org/story/columbia-classmates-recall-gorsuchs-time-new-york-scotus-trump/ |url-status=live }}</ref> As an undergraduate student, he wrote for the ''[[Columbia Daily Spectator]]'' student newspaper.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19851001-01.1.3&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN------ |title=Columbia Daily Spectator |date=October 1, 1985 |publisher=spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu |access-date=January 31, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231852/http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19851001-01.1.3&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN------ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19851001-01.2.8&srpos=10&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN-neil%20gorsuch----- |title=Columbia Daily Spectator |date=October 1, 1985 |publisher=spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu |access-date=February 1, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231904/http://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/cgi-bin/columbia?a=d&d=cs19851001-01.2.8&srpos=10&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN-neil+gorsuch----- |url-status=live }}</ref> In 1986, he co-founded the alternative Columbia student newspaper ''[[The Fed (Columbia newspaper)|The Fed]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=The History of Columbia's Oldest Student Paper |url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/thefed/v3/volume15/5/fedhistory.shtml |first=Laurie |last=Marhoefer |publisher=[[The Fed (Columbia newspaper)|The Fed]] |date=December 1, 1999 |access-date=January 28, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231848/http://www.columbia.edu/cu/thefed/v3/volume15/5/fedhistory.shtml |url-status=live }}</ref>

Gorsuch then attended [[Harvard Law School]], receiving a [[Harry S. Truman Scholarship]] to attend.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.truman.gov/joseph-e-stevens-award/ |title=Joseph E. Stevens Award | The Harry S. Truman Scholarship Foundation |website=Truman.gov |access-date=April 3, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213223108/https://www.truman.gov/joseph-e-stevens-award/ |archive-date=December 13, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name="HarvLawTod01312017">[http://today.law.harvard.edu/president-trump-nominates-neil-m-gorsuch-91-u-s-supreme-court Neil M. Gorsuch '91 nominated to the U.S. Supreme Court] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231855/https://today.law.harvard.edu/president-trump-nominates-neil-m-gorsuch-91-u-s-supreme-court/ |date=February 14, 2021 }}, ''Harvard Law Today'', January 31, 2017.</ref> He was described as a committed conservative who supported the [[Gulf War]] and [[Term limits in the United States|congressional term limits]] on "a campus full of ardent liberals".<ref>{{cite news |last=Levenson |first=Michael |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/02/01/harvard-law-gorsuch-known-for-congenial-conservatism/VVWPaO55Xm2WSO6yyfAilM/story.html |title=At Harvard Law, Gorsuch stood out on a campus full of liberals |work=[[Boston Globe]] |date=February 2, 2017 |access-date=February 25, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231858/https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/02/01/harvard-law-gorsuch-known-for-congenial-conservatism/VVWPaO55Xm2WSO6yyfAilM/story.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Former President [[Barack Obama]] was one of Gorsuch's classmates at Harvard Law.<ref name="JGersteinPol01312017">{{cite news |last=Gerstein |first=Josh |date=January 31, 2017 |title=Neil Gorsuch is Trump's SCOTUS nominee |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/who-is-neil-gorsuch-bio-facts-background-political-views-234437 |newspaper=[[Politico]] |location=Washington, DC |access-date=January 31, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231852/https://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/who-is-neil-gorsuch-bio-facts-background-political-views-234437 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="bbclaw">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38818482 |title=Supreme Court Neil Gorsuch: Who is Trump's nominee? |publisher=BBC |access-date=February 1, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231741/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38818482 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="BosDay02012017">{{cite news |last=Clauss |first=Kyle Scott |date=February 1, 2017 |title=Neil Gorsuch, Trump's Supreme Court Pick, Attended Harvard Law with Obama |url=http://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/blog/2017/02/01/neil-gorsuch-trump-supreme-court-harvard-law |newspaper=[[Boston (magazine)|Boston]] |location=[[Boston, Massachusetts]] |access-date=February 3, 2017 |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202151116/http://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/blog/2017/02/01/neil-gorsuch-trump-supreme-court-harvard-law/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Gorsuch was an editor of the ''[[Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy]]'',<ref name=fed/><ref name=record/> and graduated from Harvard Law in 1991 with a [[Juris Doctor]] ''[[Latin honors#North America|cum laude]]''.

In 2004, Gorsuch received a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in law (legal philosophy) from the [[University of Oxford]],<!--University College, Oxford does NOT award degrees--> where he completed research on [[assisted suicide]] and [[euthanasia]] as a postgraduate student of [[University College, Oxford]].<ref name=dphil>{{cite thesis |degree=DPhil |publisher=[[University of Oxford]] |title=The right to receive assistance in suicide and euthanasia, with particular reference to the law of the United States |first=Neil McGill |last=Gorsuch |date=2004 |url=https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:688e5b8c-bb06-4d86-abe0-440a7666ffc1 |id={{EThOS|uk.bl.ethos.401384}} |website=ora.ox.ac.uk |oclc=59196002 |access-date=February 15, 2017 |archive-date=March 31, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331142804/https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:688e5b8c-bb06-4d86-abe0-440a7666ffc1 |url-status=live }} {{free access}}</ref><ref name=fed/><ref name=record/> A [[Marshall Scholarship]] enabled him to study at Oxford in 1992–93, where he was supervised by the [[natural law]] philosopher [[John Finnis]] of [[University College, Oxford]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Warren |first1=Ashley |title=Judge Neil M. Gorsuch ('92) sworn in to US Supreme Court – Association of Marshall Scholars |url=https://www.marshallscholars.org/in-the-news/judge-neil-m-gorsuch-92-sworn-in-to-us-supreme-court/ |website=www.marshallscholars.org |publisher=Association of Marshall Scholars |access-date=March 2, 2019}}</ref> His thesis was also supervised by Professor [[Timothy Endicott]] of [[Balliol College, Oxford]].<ref name=dphil/><ref name="auto"/><ref name=contender/> In 1996, Gorsuch married Louise, an Englishwoman and champion [[Equestrianism|equestrienne]] on Oxford's riding team whom he met during his stay there.<ref name=WashPo19Feb/><ref>{{Cite news |title=British family of Donald Trump Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch 'thrilled but terrified' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/01/british-family-donald-trump-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch/ |first=Gordon |last=Rayner |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=February 1, 2017 |newspaper=The Telegraph |access-date=October 7, 2018 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231740/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/01/british-family-donald-trump-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Early legal career ==
=== Clerkships ===
Gorsuch served as a [[law clerk]] for Judge [[David B. Sentelle]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit]] from 1991 to 1992. After spending a year at Oxford as a Marshall Scholar, Gorsuch clerked for [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] Justices [[Byron White]] and [[Anthony Kennedy]] from 1993 to 1994.<ref name=record/><ref name="HarvLawTod01312017"/><ref>The same 1993 Term, Gorsuch's Harvard Law School classmates David T. Goldberg (HLS 1991) and [[Julius Genachowski]] (HLS 1991) both [[Law clerk of the Supreme Court of the United States|clerked]] for Justice David Souter.</ref> His work with White occurred right after White retired from the Supreme Court; therefore, Gorsuch assisted White with his work on the Tenth Circuit, where White sat by designation.<ref name=record/> Gorsuch was part of a group of five law clerks assigned that year that included [[Brett Kavanaugh]], who described Gorsuch at the time, saying: "He fit into the place very easily. He's just an easy guy to get along with. He doesn't have sharp elbows. We had a wide range of views, but we all really got along well."<ref>Greenya, John (2018). ''Gorsuch: The Judge Who Speaks for Himself''. Threshold Editions. Page 55.</ref>

=== Private law practice ===
Instead of joining an established law firm, Gorsuch decided to join the two-year-old boutique firm Kellogg, Huber, Hansen, Todd, Evans & Figel (now [[Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick]]), where he focused on trial work.<ref name=WashPo19Feb/> After winning his first trial as lead attorney, a jury member told Gorsuch he was like [[Perry Mason]].<ref name=WashPo19Feb/> He was an associate in the Washington, D.C., law firm from 1995 to 1997 and a partner from 1998 to 2005.<ref name="record">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W6gziQydtBwC&pg=PA289 |journal=[[Congressional Record|Congressional Record—Senate]]|title=Neil M. Gorsuch|volume=152|issue=11|page=15346|date=July 20, 2006|via=[[Google Books]]|access-date=June 12, 2017|isbn=978-0-16-086155-0|last1=Congress}}</ref><ref name=nlj>{{cite news|title=Three Things to Know About Neil Gorsuch, SCOTUS Front-Runner|url=http://www.nationallawjournal.com/home/id=1202777522924/Three-Things-to-Know-About-Neil-Gorsuch-SCOTUS-FrontRunner|first=Tony|last=Mauro|work=[[The National Law Journal]]|date=January 24, 2017|access-date=January 27, 2017|archive-date=February 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231744/https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/almID/1202777522924/Three-Things-to-Know-About-Neil-Gorsuch-SCOTUS-FrontRunner/?slreturn=20210114181734|url-status=live}}{{paywall}}</ref> Gorsuch's clients included Colorado billionaire [[Philip Anschutz]].<ref name=NYT15march>{{cite news|last1=Charlie Savage|author-link=Charlie Savage (author)|last2=Julie Turkewitz|title=Neil Gorsuch Has Web of Ties to Secretive Billionaire|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court.html|access-date=March 20, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 15, 2017|page=A1|archive-date=February 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231744/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court.html|url-status=live}}</ref> At Kellogg Huber, Gorsuch focused on commercial matters, including [[Contract law|contracts]], [[Competition law|antitrust]], [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act|RICO]], and [[securities fraud]].<ref name=record/>

In 2002, Gorsuch wrote an op-ed criticizing the Senate for delaying the nominations of [[Merrick Garland]] and [[John Roberts]] to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]], writing, "the most impressive judicial nominees are grossly mistreated" by the Senate.<ref name="ALiptakNYT01312017"/>

In 2005, at Kellogg Huber, Gorsuch wrote a [[brief (law)|brief]] denouncing [[class action lawsuit]]s by attorneys on behalf of [[shareholder]]s. In the case of ''[[Dura Pharmaceuticals, Inc. v. Broudo]]'', Gorsuch opined, "The free ride to fast riches enjoyed by securities class action attorneys in recent years appeared to hit a speed bump" and "the problem is that securities fraud litigation imposes an enormous toll on the economy, affecting virtually every public corporation in America at one time or another and costing businesses billions of dollars in settlements every year".<ref name=nlj/>

=== U.S. Department of Justice ===
Gorsuch served as Principal Deputy to the [[United States Associate Attorney General|Associate Attorney General]], [[Robert McCallum Jr.|Robert McCallum]], at the [[United States Department of Justice]] from 2005 until 2006.<ref name="record"/><ref name="HarvLawTod01312017"/> As McCallum's principal deputy, he assisted in managing the Department of Justice's civil litigation components, which included the antitrust, civil, [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]], environment, and tax divisions.<ref name="record"/>

While managing the [[United States Department of Justice Civil Division]], Gorsuch was tasked with all the "terror litigation" arising from the president's [[War on Terror]], successfully defending the [[extraordinary rendition]] of [[Khalid El-Masri]], fighting the disclosure of [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse]] photographs, and, in November 2005, traveling to inspect the [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Charlie Savage|author-link=Charlie Savage (author)|title=Neil Gorsuch Helped Defend Disputed Bush-Era Terror Policies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/15/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-torture-guantanamo-bay.html|access-date=March 20, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 16, 2017|page=A13|archive-date=February 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231859/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/15/us/politics/neil-gorsuch-torture-guantanamo-bay.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

Gorsuch helped Attorney General [[Alberto Gonzales]] prepare for hearings after the public revelation of [[NSA warrantless surveillance (2001–07)]], and worked with Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] in drafting the provisions in the [[Detainee Treatment Act]] that attempted to strip federal courts of jurisdiction over the detainees.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Charlie Savage|author-link=Charlie Savage (author)|title=Newly Public Emails Hint at Gorsuch's View of Presidential Power|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/18/us/politics/supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch-bush-era.html|access-date=March 20, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 19, 2017|pages=A15|archive-date=March 19, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170319202319/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/18/us/politics/supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch-bush-era.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Civil rights ===
In ''[[Planned Parenthood]] v. [[Gary Herbert|Herbert]]'' (2016), Gorsuch wrote for the four dissenting judges when the Tenth Circuit denied a full rehearing of a divided panel opinion that had ordered the Utah governor to resume the organization's funding, which Herbert had blocked in response to a [[Planned Parenthood 2015 undercover videos controversy|video controversy]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Robert|last=Barnes|title=Rulings offer glimpse into what kind of justice Gorsuch would be|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/rulings-offer-glimpse-into-what-kind-of-justice-gorsuch-would-be/2017/03/16/47e461be-081d-11e7-b77c-0047d15a24e0_story.html|access-date=March 20, 2017|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 18, 2017|page=A1|archive-date=March 19, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170319165829/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/rulings-offer-glimpse-into-what-kind-of-justice-gorsuch-would-be/2017/03/16/47e461be-081d-11e7-b77c-0047d15a24e0_story.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=10813564172838744283&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 ''Planned Parenthood Association of Utah v. Herbert''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231902/https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=10813564172838744283&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 |date=February 14, 2021 }}, 839 F.3d 1301 (10th Cir. 2016).</ref>

In ''A.M. v. Holmes'' (2016), the Tenth Circuit considered a case in which a 13-year-old child was arrested for burping and laughing in gym class. The child was handcuffed and arrested based on a [[New Mexico]] statute that makes it a [[misdemeanor]] to disrupt school activities. The child's family brought a federal [[42 U.S.C. § 1983|§ 1983]] civil rights action against school officials and the [[school resource officer]] who made the arrest, arguing that it was a [[false arrest]] that violated the child's constitutional rights. In a 94-page majority opinion, the Tenth Circuit held that the defendants enjoyed [[qualified immunity]] from suit.<ref name="fm">{{cite news|date=July 25, 2016|title=A.M., on behalf of her minor child, F.M. v. Ann Holmes; Principal Susan Labarge; Arthur Acosta, City of Albuquerque Police Officer, in his individual capacity|url=http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/opinions/14/14-2066.pdf|publisher=United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit|access-date=February 1, 2017|archive-date=January 31, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131033907/http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/opinions/14/14-2066.pdf|url-status=live}} Majority finding on qualified immunity, pp. 93-94; Gorsuch dissent, pp. 1-4.</ref> Gorsuch wrote a four-page dissent, arguing that the [[New Mexico Court of Appeals]] had "long ago alerted law enforcement" that the statute that the officer relied upon for the child's arrest does not criminalize noises or diversions that merely disturb order in a classroom.<ref name="fm"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Feldman|first=Noah|date=July 27, 2016|title=A Belch in Gym Class. Then Handcuffs and a Lawsuit.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-07-27/a-belch-in-gym-class-then-handcuffs-and-a-lawsuit|newspaper=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|access-date=February 1, 2017|archive-date=February 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202145441/https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-07-27/a-belch-in-gym-class-then-handcuffs-and-a-lawsuit|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Sandlin|first=Scott|date=July 28, 2016|title=Burp arrest of 7th-grader upheld by fed appeals court|url=https://www.abqjournal.com/816203/burp-arrest-upheld-by-fed-court.html|newspaper=[[Albuquerque Journal]]|access-date=February 1, 2017|archive-date=September 6, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160906103639/https://www.abqjournal.com/816203/burp-arrest-upheld-by-fed-court.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Criminal law ===
In 2009, Gorsuch wrote for a unanimous panel finding that a court may still order criminals to pay [[restitution]] even after it missed a statutory deadline.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12419626530580981904&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 ''United States v. Dolan''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231918/https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12419626530580981904&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 |date=February 14, 2021 }}, 571 F.3d 1022 (10th Cir. 2009).</ref> The Supreme Court affirmed that ruling 5–4 in ''Dolan v. United States'' (2010).<ref name=bloombergJAN2/>

In ''United States v. Games-Perez'' (2012), Gorsuch ruled on a case where a [[felon]] owned a gun in violation of {{USC|18|922}}(g)(1), but alleged that he did not know that he was a felon at the time. Gorsuch joined the majority in upholding the conviction based on Tenth Circuit precedent, but filed a concurring opinion arguing that said precedent was wrongly decided: "The only statutory element separating innocent (even constitutionally protected) gun possession from criminal conduct in §§ 922(g) and 924(a) is a prior felony conviction. So the presumption that the government must prove [[mens rea]] here applies with full force."<ref>{{cite web|title=United States of America v. Miguel Games-Perez|url=http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/opinions/11/11-1011.pdf|publisher=[[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit]]|date=September 17, 2012|access-date=January 27, 2017|archive-date=February 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207001524/http://www.ca10.uscourts.gov/opinions/11/11-1011.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> In the 2019 case ''[[Rehaif v. United States]]'', the Supreme Court overruled this decision, with Gorsuch joining.

In 2013, Gorsuch joined a unanimous panel finding that intent does not need to be proven under a bank fraud statute.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=5578655094963796612&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 ''United States v. Loughrin''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231918/https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=5578655094963796612&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 |date=February 14, 2021 }}, 710 F.3d 1111 (10th Cir. 2013)</ref> A unanimous Supreme Court affirmed that ruling in ''Loughrin v. United States'' (2014).<ref name=bloombergJAN2/> In 2015, Gorsuch wrote a dissent to the denial of rehearing ''en banc'' when the Tenth Circuit found that a convicted sex offender had to register with Kansas after he moved to the Philippines.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13383292750573368126&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 ''United States v. Nichols''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231845/https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=13383292750573368126&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 |date=February 14, 2021 }}, 784 F. 3d 666, 667 (10th 2015) (Gorsuch, J., dissenting from denial of rehearing en banc).</ref> A unanimous Supreme Court reversed the Tenth Circuit in ''[[Nichols v. United States]]'' (2016).<ref name=bloombergJAN2/>

=== Death penalty ===
Gorsuch favors a strict reading of the [[Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996]] (AEDPA).<ref name=scotusblog1/> In 2015, he wrote for the court when it permitted Oklahoma attorney general [[Scott Pruitt]] to order the execution of Scott Eizember, prompting a 30-page dissent by Judge [[Mary Beck Briscoe]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Court upholds death penalty in deadly 2003 Oklahoma crime spree|url=http://newsok.com/article/5447108|first=Robert|last=Boczkiewicz|newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=September 15, 2015|access-date=January 27, 2017|archive-date=June 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621101007/http://newsok.com/article/5447108|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8895269800790580321&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 ''Eizember v. Trammell''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231921/https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8895269800790580321&hl=en&as_sdt=2006 |date=February 14, 2021 }}, 803 F.3d 1129 (10th Cir. 2015).</ref> After the state's unsuccessful [[execution of Clayton Lockett]], Gorsuch joined Briscoe when the court unanimously allowed Pruitt to continue using the same lethal injection protocol. The Supreme Court upheld that ruling 5–4 in ''[[Glossip v. Gross]]'' (2015).<ref name=glossip>{{cite journal|url=http://cdn.harvardlawreview.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/glossip_v_gross.pdf|title=The Supreme Court, 2014 Term: Leading Cases|volume=129|journal=Harvard Law Review|page=171|year=2015|access-date=February 2, 2017|archive-date=December 20, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220101657/http://cdn.harvardlawreview.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/glossip_v_gross.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Judicial activism ===
[[File:LB1 9414.jpg|thumb|left|Gorsuch in 2019]]
In a 2016 speech at [[Case Western Reserve University]], Gorsuch said that judges should strive to apply the law as it is, focusing backward, not forward, and looking to text, structure, and history to decide what a reasonable reader at the time of the events in question would have understood the law to be—not to decide cases based on their own moral convictions or the policy consequences they believe might serve society best.<ref name=supreme>{{cite news |title=How Neil Gorsuch could end up as Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/25/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court |first=Ariane |last=de Vogue |work=CNN|date=January 25, 2017 |access-date=January 27, 2017 |archive-date=February 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231927/https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/25/politics/neil-gorsuch-supreme-court |url-status=live }}</ref>

He wrote that, in doing so, American liberals are circumventing the democratic process on issues like [[gay marriage]], [[school vouchers]], and [[assisted suicide]], and this has led to a compromised judiciary, which is no longer independent.
